chapter.htmlHeader: What are the complications?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Portal hypertension (a pathologic increase in portal venous pressure) is one of the earliest sequelae of cirrhosis, and many complications of cirrhosis arise as a result of this rather than hepatocyte failure [Tsochatzis et al, 2014; Muir, 2015; Garcia-Tsao et al, 2017]. 
  • The major complications of cirrhosis are [Runyon, 2012]: 
    • Ascites 
      • Ascites is fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity as a result of splanchnic vasodilation and sodium and water retention [Muir, 2015]. It causes abdominal swelling, bloating, and pain, and is the most common complication of cirrhosis often necessitating hospital admission [Runyon, 2012; Muir, 2015]. 
      • Hepatic hydrothorax occurs in around 1 in 20 people with cirrhosis and ascites. This is a large pleural effusion, (usually on the right side) resulting from fluid passing through a defect in the diaphragm into the pleural space [Runyon, 2012].
      • People with cirrhosis and ascites are at high risk of further complications such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, hyponatraemia, and hepatorenal syndrome [European Association for the Study of the Liver, 2010].
    • Hepatic encephalopathy
      • Hepatic encephalopathy is a dysfunction of the brain as a result of liver insufficiency and/or portosystemic shunting [Shawcross et al, 2016] and is related to the effect of nitrogenous waste products (such as ammonia and glutamine) on the brain [Ellul et al, 2015]. It is a frequent and debilitating complication of cirrhosis [Vilstrup et al, 2014; National Guideline Centre, 2016], affecting quality of life and increasing the person's risk of accidents [Flamm, 2017]. 
      • It presents with a variety of symptoms, including cognitive and behavioural changes (for example irritability, disinhibition, disorientation), personality changes, sleep disturbance, motor problems, and altered level of consciousness [Vilstrup et al, 2014; National Guideline Centre, 2016; Shawcross et al, 2016]. Symptoms vary in severity, with mild hepatic encephalopathy only detectable using psychometric or neurophysiological testing and severe cases experiencing acute confusion, agitation, and coma [Ellul et al, 2015; Shawcross et al, 2016].
      • Hepatic encephalopathy affects around half of people with cirrhosis some time after diagnosis (5–25% within five years and around 1 in 5 people with cirrhosis each year), and is more common in people with other evidence of decompensated liver disease [Ellul et al, 2015; National Guideline Centre, 2016; NICE, 2016]. 
      • It is usually associated with a predisposing event, for example, constipation, dehydration, infection, gastrointestinal bleeding, or drugs (for example opiates, benzodiazepines, diuretics) [Vilstrup et al, 2014; Tsochatzis et al, 2014; Ellul et al, 2015; Keane et al, 2016].
    • Haemorrhage from oesophageal varices
      • The increase in portal pressure causes varices as a result of dilation of veins in the oesophagus and stomach [Muir, 2015]. Rupture of varices and associated bleeding, which can present as haematemesis or melaena, has a high mortality rate [World Gastroenterology Organisation, 2014; Ge and Runyon, 2016]. Risk factors for rupture include size of varices, severity of liver disease, sepsis, and hepatocellular carcinoma [Keane et al, 2016]. 
      • Gastro-oesophageal varices occur in around half of people with cirrhosis, but this is dependent on the clinical stage. Fewer people with compensated cirrhosis have varices (30–40%) compared with decompensated cirrhosis (up to 85%) [Garcia-Tsao et al, 2017].
    • Infection
      • People with cirrhosis are at increased risk of bacterial infection and sepsis because of immune dysfunction resulting from cirrhosis. The most commonly occurring infections in this group are spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (when the body's natural bacteria cause infection of ascitic fluid), urinary tract infection, pneumonia, cellulitis, and bacteraemia [Fernandez and Arroyo, 2013; Jalan et al, 2014].  
      • Bacterial infections have a significant role in progression of liver failure, development of complications, and mortality in people with cirrhosis [Jalan et al, 2014]. The body's response to infection increases the risk of serious complications such as shock and renal failure because of the haemodynamic dysfunction that is already present in cirrhosis [Bunchorntavakul, 2016].  
      • Risk factors for infection in people with cirrhosis include reduced liver function, low protein ascites, and variceal bleeding [Fernandez and Arroyo, 2013]. 
      • Around a third of bacterial infections are acquired in the community [Fernandez and Arroyo, 2013] and the incidence of resistant bacteria has increased in recent years [Jalan et al, 2014]. 
  • Other complications include [Moller and Henriksen, 2008; Low et al, 2015]  [Muir, 2015; Ge and Runyon, 2016; British Liver Trust and RCGP, 2017] : 
    • Hepatorenal syndrome — results from changes to the circulation due to the effects of cirrhosis, plus sodium and water retention and renal vasoconstriction. The resulting decrease in renal blood flow leads to a reduced glomerular filtration rate and hepatorenal syndrome.
    • Hepatocellular carcinoma.
    • Portal hypertensive gastropathy.
    • Portal vein thrombosis.
    • Cardiovascular complications including circulatory changes (such as decreased blood pressure), and cirrhotic cardiomyopathy.
